Will toe acted To-morrow, and every Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday.
*+* It having been found impossible to produce the New Ballet (without additional rehearsals) in that manner which the patrons of this theatre have a right to expect* and are, it is hoped, accustomed to witness: its production is necessarily delayed until TO-MORROW ; and the numerous parties who have secured places have the option of their money being returned* or their seats being transferred.

The Chinese Quadrille on Chinese airs, including the
National Hymn, by Confucius.	- Jullien
Sinfcnia, -	“ The Power of Sound.” •
Solo,Cornet aPiston,HerrK(Bnig.
Valse - I’he Bird of Paradise - Koenig
A Grand Descriptive Fantasia, selected from Koch Albert’s Opera, entitled The
De struction of Pompeii!
WITH 300 CHORUS.
Description.—1. Selection from the Overture, in which is heard the first warning of the for thcoming eruption. 2 Introduction ; Pagan Hymn, attributed to Pylhagorus, and composed on the ancient system of the Tetracord. 3. Continuation of the Overture. 4. Chorus of Mariners quitting the shore. 5. Consul tation of the Oracle. 6. Cavatina from Act 2.	7. Fete of
Terpsichore ; Dances of the Bacchanals. 8. Chorus of Bacchanals, interrupted by the incr easing thunder and explosion of the mountain. Sudden dai kness prevails, and the people, in their consternation, rush in crowds to the Temple of Isis, beseech, ing, in accents of despair, the intercession of the Idol. Fxpfo* sion of the Crater, Falling oj the Temples, and total Destruction of the City.
PART II.
Prologue to the Ballet of Alma.	- Costa
Quadrille, The Irish Echos. fcolo, Ophicleide, M. Prospere,
Variations on " Rule Britannia,” - Deloffre
Valse - The Bouquet Royal - Jullien
The English Quadrille,
Printed and Published, every Morning, by E. J. Thomas. 25, Bussell Court, Bryages Street, Coient Garden.

Order of the New Scenery and Incidental Dances :—
Scene 1—Interior of a rich Goldsmith’s Shop. Scene 2—Canal of Ghent, in which is represented a Flemish Fe e, after Teniers, introductory of I,e Fas de I/Ivrogne, by Messrs Fayne, Dclferier. and Madame Petit Stephan, and terminating with a grand Analogous Procession. Fas Seal, by Madlle. C. Webster, Fas de Deux, by Monsieur H. Vestris and Mademoiselle Fleury. Scene 3— Chamber of Beatrice. Act 2—( Venice)—Scene 4—Boudoir of the Marquis San Lucar. Scene 5—Splendid Illuminated Pavi ion, where will be introduced a Grand Divertissement, consisting of Pas Crncovien, hy Monsieur Delferier and Mademoiselle Webster; Fas de Nayades, hy Mademoiselle O’Bryan, accompanied hy Madlle. Carson, Hartley, Sutton, and Travis ; Fas de Deux, by Monsieur Hognet Vestris and Madame Petit Stephan ; Fas de Diane, Aveo Poses Antiques, by Mademoiselle Fleury, accompanied by her Huntresses, Mesdames Hunt, Barnett, &c.	Act 3—( Venice and Ghent) —Scene 6—Park
and Villa of the Marquis; Tableau of a Venetian Orgie, sncceeded by a Variety of Groups from the Antique ; Pas de Flore, by Madame P. Stephan, attended by Mademoiselles Barnett. Heed, &c; Scene 7—The Marquis’s Boudoir, (as before) ; Scene 8—Ancient Ruins on the Canal of Ghent; Scene 9, and Last—Chamber of Beatrice, (as before), wherein the actiou of the Ballet, in the preceding eight Scenes is supposed to pass in a dream.

SCENE 0. AND LAST— CHAMBER OF BEATRICE, («before.)
Wherein the action of the Ballet, in the preceding eight Scenes, is supposed to pass in a dream.
tt'e Doors will open at Half-past Six, and the Performance will commence at Seven precisely.

Scenes 8 ami 9.—PBIWPECT PLACE ANB EABM.
A pretty PROSPECT, but a bad LOOK OUT—a Change being DESIRABLE, a Change for the better takes place—Cold Water Cure an Infallible Remedy—a Whip sometimes better
for a Man than a Horse—a Bed of Roses, how to make it, and who ought to he on it.
Scene 10.-- OUTSIDE OF ’CORK STOUT' HOUSE, „	'	.	,
Cork Stout and Stout Cork—an Organic Defect remedied by anOrgamc Change—“ He wouid be a Soldier’—-New Regulation Tile—Derby Sweeps, 1S44—Running Horses, and Colours of •e	the Riders—“Off they go”—False Start—novel winning post—settling day—Defaulters—a gev.raJ row te escape corporal punishment.
Scene u....EXTERMOU0F iOVFM TIO.lFH'S SHOP.
Preparations on a LARGE Scale for Twelfth Night—Slippery Ice and sudden Thaw—REAL Hare and Ox-tail Soup—Turtle All Alive—Thorough-^red GingberJraid—Trijles at a moderate figure—Effects of Indulging in Wedding Cake—remaikable Twelfth Cake and Tableau V lvant—Dance by the Characters—Crackers in a State of Eruption—ending in a
SCENE OF EXTRAORPINARY ANIMATION.
